title: LIBERTy: A Causal Framework for Benchmarking Concept-Based Explanations of LLMs with Structural Counterfactuals
summary: This paper introduces LIBERTy, a novel causal framework designed to benchmark concept-based explanations of Large Language Models (LLMs) using structural counterfactuals, addressing the limitations of costly and imperfect human-written counterfactuals. LIBERTy constructs datasets by defining Structured Causal Models (SCMs) where concept interventions propagate to LLMs for counterfactual generation. The framework, applied across medical and other high-stakes domains, reveals significant room for improving explanation methods and highlights reduced sensitivity of proprietary LLMs to demographic concepts, likely due to post-training mitigation.

title: Sporadic Creutzfeldt Jakob disease presenting with cerebral atrophy following traumatic brain injury mimicking hydrocephalus a case report and literature review
summary: This paper presents a case of sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (sCJD) in a patient who initially exhibited symptoms and imaging findings (cerebral ventricle dilation post-TBI) that mimicked hydrocephalus. The study details the diagnostic process, which eventually confirmed sCJD through specific CSF biomarkers (14-3-3 and tau proteins), characteristic MRI findings, and EEG abnormalities. It underscores the critical importance of a comprehensive differential diagnosis to distinguish rare neurodegenerative diseases from more common conditions.

title: Jordan-Segmentable Masks: A Topology-Aware definition for characterizing Binary Image Segmentation
summary: This paper introduces "Jordan-segmentable masks," a novel topology-aware definition for binary image segmentation, designed to address the limitations of conventional metrics in capturing structural and topological coherence. By leveraging the Jordan Curve Theorem, digital topology, and homology theory, it provides a mathematically rigorous, unsupervised criterion to ensure segmentation masks partition an image into meaningful interior and exterior regions, crucial for applications like medical imaging.

title: ErrEval: Error-Aware Evaluation for Question Generation through Explicit Diagnostics
summary: ErrEval proposes an innovative Error-aware Evaluation framework for Automatic Question Generation (QG) to address critical defects like factual hallucinations and answer mismatches, which are often overlooked by existing holistic evaluation methods. It reformulates evaluation as a two-stage process involving explicit error diagnosis followed by informed LLM scoring. Experiments confirm ErrEval's effectiveness in improving alignment with human judgments and mitigating the overestimation of low-quality questions.

title: A Predictive Model for Synergistic Oncolytic Virotherapy: Unveiling the Ping-Pong Mechanism and Optimal Timing of Combined Vesicular Stomatitis and Vaccinia Viruses
summary: This paper presents a mathematical model elucidating a novel 'ping-pong' synergistic mechanism for combined Vesicular Stomatitis Virus (VSV) and Vaccinia Virus (VV) oncolytic virotherapy, where VV-produced B18R protein neutralizes interferon-$α$ to enhance VSV replication. Numerical simulations predict complete tumor clearance in 50 days, representing an 11% acceleration over VV monotherapy, with optimal therapeutic outcomes achieved by immediate VSV administration followed by delayed VV injection within a 1-19 day window.

title: Handling Missing Modalities in Multimodal Survival Prediction for Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
summary: Accurate survival prediction in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) requires the integration of heterogeneous clinical, radiological, and histopathological information. While Multimodal Deep Learning (MDL) offers a promises for precision prognosis and survival prediction, its clinical applicability i...

title: PLGC: Pseudo-Labeled Graph Condensation
summary: PLGC introduces a self-supervised graph condensation method that addresses the computational cost of training Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) on large, potentially noisy datasets by generating small synthetic graphs. Unlike existing approaches, PLGC operates without ground-truth labels, constructing latent pseudo-labels from node embeddings to optimize condensed graphs that preserve the original graph's structural and feature statistics. It achieves competitive performance on clean data and demonstrates substantial robustness, often outperforming supervised baselines under label noise and distribution shift.

title: EvoMorph: Counterfactual Explanations for Continuous Time-Series Extrinsic Regression Applied to Photoplethysmography
summary: EvoMorph introduces a multi-objective evolutionary framework for generating physiologically plausible and diverse counterfactual explanations (CFE) for Time-Series Extrinsic Regression (TSER) models applied to continuous biomedical signals like photoplethysmography (PPG). It addresses the limitations of existing CFE methods by optimizing morphology-aware objectives and preserving waveform structure, thereby enabling uncertainty-aware interpretability crucial for clinical trust and reasoning.

title: C-GRASP: Clinically-Grounded Reasoning for Affective Signal Processing
summary: C-GRASP introduces a guardrailed RAG-enhanced pipeline to mitigate physiological hallucinations in Large Language Model (LLM) interpretation of Heart Rate Variability (HRV) for affective signal processing. By integrating an individualized Z-score Priority Hierarchy and RSA-aware guardrails, the system achieves superior emotion classification accuracy and high clinical reasoning consistency, fostering transparent, evidence-based clinical decision support.

title: coTherapist: A Behavior-Aligned Small Language Model to Support Mental Healthcare Experts
summary: coTherapist is a novel framework utilizing a small language model (SLM) engineered through domain-specific fine-tuning, retrieval augmentation, and agentic reasoning to support mental healthcare experts. It generates clinically grounded and relevant responses, exhibits high empathy and therapist-consistent personality traits, and was validated by human experts for accuracy, trustworthiness, and safety, demonstrating the potential of SLMs for expert-like behavior in digital mental health.
